content.content: Hey there - thanks for reaching out - I took a few days off the celebrate American Independence.     MakerWOW:  I mean, is there a process or committee to ensure information like this about delegates is accurate   Nope. It’s the wild west right now. There isn’t even a process to ensure that each delegate is a unique human being. I’d like to figure out how to implement some level of sybil-resistance for delegates at some point.     MakerWOW:  I am interested to hear your thoughts and opinions (and again, those of anyone else who feel they can help provide some insight) on what exactly seems to be happening right now inside MakerDAO…?   There is a struggle going on inside of MakerDAO right now that can be summed up like this: one side believes that the DAO should operate in a maximally-decentralized, censorship-resistant, transparent, trustless way (I fall on this side). The other side believes that the DAO should maximize efficiency, speed and growth by creating small executive decision-making teams, centralizing power via multisigs, and so on. I believe that a DAO should be maximally-decentralized. Any centralization of power increases regulatory attack surface, and also opens up new avenues for whales/VCs to decrease transparency, run the DAO with their mega-voting power via delegates and shadow delegates, and ultimately create a “decentralization theatre” situation. I am firmly against this and have been for years. You will find that some of the people who are suggesting more centralization and more “executive rulemaking” for the DAO are also people who are suggesting that they should be given those executive roles. Beware of this type of incentive misalignment.     MakerWOW:  I can’t quite tell if you were also saying that you disagree with the entire idea of allocating any of Maker’s funds to any ETFs, Treasuries, and other TradFi instruments…   Historically I have been against real-world finance in general for DAOs for the simple reason that it is absolutely impossible to do this trustlessly. The current proposal for Monetalis to execute Maker’s treasury strategy is also controversial because Monetalis is owned by MKR whales, hence incentive misalignment. There are many, many points of trust required to conduct this type of stuff and I generally believe that we should be minimizing trust. I haven’t completely ruled out RWF because I believe that there is a way to do is in a trust-minimized way unto itself. Giving multisigs control of tens or hundreds of millions of dollars is wrong. Giving a 3rd party control of even more of the DAO’s money (as long as they give us delayed “transparency reports”) is wrong. The DAO deserves to have its eyes on the money at all times. This is what open blockchain tech is all about. It’s why we’re here. This would be inefficient, but it would reduce attack surface as much as possible. I think this could work. However, I don’t think that anyone involved with RWF right now is interested in giving up control or efficiency. It seems like it’s turning into an all-or-nothing endeavor for the DAO. If that is indeed the case, then I would be on the “nothing” side. Feel free to reach out with any other questions or thoughts, and delegate to me if you think I’m lining up with your philosophy on the DAO.
